name: Choking Adult
description: Airway obstruction in adults requiring Heimlich maneuver

steps.text: Assess the situation: Ask 'Are you choking?' If the person cannot speak, cough forcefully, or breathe, they have a severe obstruction requiring immediate action
Call 911 or direct someone specific to call. Say 'You in the red shirt, call 911 now!' Stay with the victim
Position yourself: Stand behind the person with one foot between their feet for stability. Wrap your arms around their waist
Hand placement: Make a fist with your dominant hand. Place thumb side against the abdomen, above the navel and well below the breastbone
Perform abdominal thrusts: Grasp your fist with your other hand. Pull sharply inward and upward in a J-shaped motion. Repeat until object is expelled or person becomes unconscious
If unconscious: Lower person to ground carefully. Call 911 if not done. Begin CPR starting with chest compressions. Check mouth for visible object before giving breaths
After object is expelled: Encourage person to seek medical evaluation. Some internal injury may have occurred from thrusts
Determine if child can cough, cry, or speak
Call 911 if complete obstruction
Kneel behind child and perform abdominal thrusts
Use less force than for adults
Continue until object is expelled or child becomes unconscious
Begin CPR if child becomes unconscious
Recognize choking: Infant cannot cry, cough, or breathe. May turn blue. Silent choking is a medical emergency
Position for back blows: Hold infant face-down along your forearm, head lower than chest. Support jaw with your hand without covering mouth
Give 5 back blows: Use heel of your hand to deliver 5 firm blows between shoulder blades. Check if object is expelled after each blow
Turn infant over: Support head and neck. Sandwich infant between forearms and turn face-up, keeping head lower than body
Give 5 chest thrusts: Place 2 fingers on breastbone just below nipple line. Give 5 quick downward thrusts about 1.5 inches deep
Repeat cycle: Continue alternating 5 back blows and 5 chest thrusts until object is expelled or infant becomes unconscious
If unconscious: Call 911. Begin infant CPR. Look in mouth before giving breaths - only remove object if clearly visible
